intro: Ranunculus pimpinellifolius var. vestitus, commonly known as the hairy buttercup, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It features delicate, bright yellow flowers with 5 to 15 petals, often adorned with a hairy covering on the sepals and leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with trifoliate leaves that are palmately arranged and covered in fine hairs. Its flowers bloom in early spring, and the plant thrives in moist, well-drained soils. It is often found in woodland edges, meadows, and along stream banks.
